deck.name: Business English Basics
deck.description: Professional vocabulary for emails, meetings, presentations and the corporate world.

cards.definition: a formal email greeting when you don't know the recipient's name
cards.context: Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to inquire about…

cards.definition: a very formal greeting for unknown recipients
cards.context: To whom it may concern, I wish to apply for the position of…

cards.definition: a standard opening to state the purpose of a formal email
cards.context: I am writing to follow up on our conversation last week.

cards.definition: a formal way to indicate a file is included with the email
cards.context: Please find attached the report for Q3.

cards.definition: referring to a previous communication or event
cards.context: Further to our meeting on Monday, I'd like to confirm the next steps.

cards.definition: indicating you are doing what was asked
cards.context: As per your request, I've updated the budget spreadsheet.

cards.term: I look forward to hearing from you
cards.definition: a polite closing expecting a reply
cards.context: I look forward to hearing from you at your earliest convenience.

cards.definition: common professional email sign-offs
cards.context: Best regards, Sophie Martin.

cards.definition: Carbon Copy (visible) / Blind Carbon Copy (hidden) — sending a copy to others
cards.context: I'll CC the manager so she's in the loop.

cards.definition: For Your Information — used to share something without requiring action
cards.context: FYI, the deadline has been moved to Friday.

cards.definition: As Soon As Possible — indicating urgency
cards.context: Please send the updated file ASAP.

cards.definition: to check on or continue something previously discussed
cards.context: I'd like to follow up on the proposal I sent last week.

cards.definition: to verify or make something definite
cards.context: Can you confirm your attendance for the meeting?

cards.definition: to change the time or date of something planned
cards.context: I need to reschedule our call to Thursday afternoon.

cards.definition: to confirm that you have received or understood something
cards.context: Please acknowledge receipt of this email.

cards.definition: a list of items to be discussed at a meeting
cards.context: I'll send the agenda before the meeting.

cards.definition: the official written record of what was said in a meeting
cards.context: Who's taking the minutes today?

cards.definition: a phrase to begin a meeting or activity
cards.context: Everyone's here. Let's get started.

cards.term: The purpose of this meeting is…
cards.definition: introducing the reason for a meeting
cards.context: The purpose of this meeting is to review the project timeline.

cards.definition: asking someone to give more details
cards.context: Interesting point. Could you elaborate on that?

cards.definition: politely contributing to a discussion
cards.context: If I may, I'd like to add one thing.

cards.definition: transitioning to the next topic
cards.context: Good discussion. Let's move on to the budget.

cards.definition: introducing a summary of what was discussed
cards.context: To sum up, we agreed on three action items.

cards.definition: a task assigned to someone as a result of a meeting
cards.context: Your action item is to draft the proposal by Friday.

cards.definition: the latest time by which something must be completed
cards.context: The deadline for submissions is March 15th.

cards.definition: offering the floor for questions
cards.context: That covers the main points. Any questions?

cards.term: I'll get back to you on that
cards.definition: promising to provide an answer later
cards.context: Good question. I'll get back to you on that by tomorrow.

cards.definition: a phone call involving multiple participants
cards.context: We have a conference call with the client at 3 PM.

cards.definition: to lead or manage a meeting
cards.context: Who's chairing the meeting today?

cards.definition: to finish or conclude something
cards.context: Let's wrap up — we've covered everything on the agenda.

cards.definition: a standard opening for a presentation
cards.context: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here.

cards.term: Today I'm going to talk about…
cards.definition: introducing the topic of a presentation
cards.context: Today I'm going to talk about our marketing strategy for 2026.

cards.definition: a phrase to begin the first section of a presentation
cards.context: Let me start by giving you some background.

cards.term: As you can see on this slide…
cards.definition: directing the audience's attention to visual content
cards.context: As you can see on this slide, sales grew by 25%.

cards.definition: transitioning between sections of a presentation
cards.context: Moving on to our third quarter results…

cards.definition: explaining a visual element in a presentation
cards.context: This chart shows the trend over the last five years.

cards.definition: introducing the final summary of a presentation
cards.context: In conclusion, we expect strong growth next quarter.

cards.definition: inviting the audience to ask questions after a presentation
cards.context: That's the end of my presentation. Are there any questions?

cards.definition: a polite closing phrase for a presentation
cards.context: Thank you for your attention. I'm happy to take questions.

cards.definition: introducing a high-level summary
cards.context: To give you an overview, the project has three phases.

cards.definition: a person with an interest or concern in a project or business
cards.context: We need to get approval from all key stakeholders.

cards.definition: Key Performance Indicator — a measurable value showing effectiveness
cards.context: Our main KPI this quarter is customer retention rate.

cards.definition: Return on Investment — the profit gained relative to the cost
cards.context: The campaign delivered a 300% ROI.

cards.definition: the total income generated by a business
cards.context: Annual revenue exceeded ten million euros.

cards.definition: the financial gain after subtracting costs from revenue
cards.context: Net profit was up 15% compared to last year.

cards.definition: the amount of money allocated for a project or period
cards.context: We need to stay within budget for this quarter.

cards.definition: a goal or objective to be achieved
cards.context: Our target is to increase sales by 20%.

cards.definition: a plan of action designed to achieve a long-term goal
cards.context: We're developing a new marketing strategy.

cards.definition: comments or opinions about something, used for improvement
cards.context: I'd appreciate your feedback on the proposal.

cards.definition: the combined effort of a group to achieve a goal
cards.context: This project's success is thanks to great teamwork.

cards.definition: a group discussion to produce ideas and find solutions
cards.context: Let's brainstorm ideas for the new campaign.

cards.definition: to assign tasks or responsibilities to others
cards.context: Learn to delegate — you can't do everything yourself.

cards.definition: to arrange tasks in order of importance
cards.context: We need to prioritize the urgent issues first.

cards.definition: to put a plan or decision into action
cards.context: How soon can we implement the new process?

cards.definition: to grow or expand a business or operation
cards.context: We need to scale our customer support to handle more requests.

cards.definition: the process of integrating a new employee into a company
cards.context: The onboarding process takes about two weeks.

cards.definition: a formal assessment of an employee's work
cards.context: I have my annual performance review next Monday.

cards.definition: an advancement to a higher position at work
cards.context: She got a promotion to senior manager.

cards.definition: time worked beyond the normal schedule
cards.context: I've been doing a lot of overtime this month.

cards.definition: working from a location outside the office, usually from home
cards.context: We offer remote work two days a week.

cards.definition: building professional relationships and contacts
cards.context: Networking events are great for finding new opportunities.

cards.definition: a document requesting payment for goods or services
cards.context: I'll send the invoice by the end of the week.

cards.definition: happening every three months
cards.context: We publish a quarterly financial report.

cards.definition: the final result, or the most important point
cards.context: The bottom line is that we need to cut costs.

cards.definition: to make brief contact with someone
cards.context: Let's touch base next week to review progress.

cards.term: to be on the same page
cards.definition: to have the same understanding of something
cards.context: Let's review the plan so we're all on the same page.

cards.term: to keep someone in the loop
cards.definition: to keep someone informed about developments
cards.context: Please keep me in the loop on any updates.

cards.definition: a rough estimate
cards.context: Can you give me a ballpark figure for the project cost?

cards.definition: to contribute or offer something valuable
cards.context: What skills do you bring to the table?

cards.definition: a situation where both sides benefit
cards.context: This partnership is a win-win for both companies.

cards.definition: to think creatively and consider unconventional ideas
cards.context: We need to think outside the box to solve this problem.

cards.definition: to use something to maximum advantage
cards.context: We should leverage social media to reach more customers.

cards.definition: the combined effect being greater than the sum of individual efforts
cards.context: The merger created great synergy between the two teams.

cards.definition: a standard or reference point for comparison
cards.context: We use industry benchmarks to measure our performance.

cards.definition: to make a process more efficient by simplifying it
cards.context: We need to streamline our approval process.

cards.definition: a set of deals or projects in progress
cards.context: We have three big deals in the pipeline.

cards.definition: the key point or lesson from a discussion
cards.context: The main takeaway is that we need to act quickly.

cards.definition: to return to a topic or discussion later
cards.context: Let's circle back to this issue after lunch.

cards.definition: a specific output or result that must be produced
cards.context: The deliverables for phase one are due next Friday.

cards.definition: to give formal approval
cards.context: The director needs to sign off on the budget.

cards.definition: an advance warning or notification
cards.context: Just a heads up — the client meeting has been moved to 2 PM.
